On the board compensation, I think the first thing we have to do is to get the share price into the board remuneration, and the bodies of the company are discussing that. And I have all indications that from next year on there will be also compensation tied to the share price of the board members. So this for me is priority over other measures. In particular as the compensation of all top managers except the board levels is tied to ROC type investment criteria as well.

So in practice, I can tell you couldn't run an organization even if there is at the moment still a difference between the board for compensation and the rest of organization, if everybody tells you – if you tell an organization, please keep on investing like hell, and they tell you, sorry, then we can't get any bonus, you wouldn't survive as a board member for long. So in practice, there is a link in the compensation scheme that still needs further discussion. But as I said first step is trying into the share and this will be implemented for next year, so in 2011 for 2012.
Are there any additional questions on the call, operator?
We will take our next question today from Edward Dulac from Barclays Capital. Your line is now open.

Thank you and good afternoon. Just a few questions, please. Firstly, with respect to Serono, sales guidance seems to imply in the case Serono approval – excuse me, cladribine approval in U.S. about €200 million or so in 2011. I am just curious if you can share with us your assumption around what label might be had in the U.S., penetration rates and timing of reimbursement?

Secondly, with respect to Rebif, in the third quarter commentary, you were be able to provide some kind of volume pricing and currency dynamics for both Europe and U.S. Hoping to get that for the fourth quarter as well?

And then lastly with respect to foreign exchange, in the quarter you said it was about 5%, I was hoping perhaps, you can give us an estimate of what – how much of that flowed through to the bottom line? Thank you.
And maybe one additional question from the call before taking Edward's question.
Our next question today comes from Vincent Meunier from Exane BNP Paribas. Your line is now open.
Hello, gentlemen. A few questions, please. The first one is on the Rebif, on the new formulation; can you please give us an update regarding the regulatory process in the U.S.?
The second question is on Stimuvax and cilengitide, can you please give us an update on the timing of the Phase III trials. When can we expect results, at least interim results?
And lastly, on OLED, can you please give us an update on the market dynamics and the future near-term opportunities for Merck and also for the industry in general? Thank you.
I'm sorry, can you repeat that.
Yeah. The third question is on the OLEDs, can you please give us an update on the market dynamics and also the near-term opportunities for Merck and the market in general?

Okay. Cladribine, I really ask for your understanding, let's wait for the U.S. decision on the 28th and then we will review the situation and then update you as soon as we have information. At the moment, it is really a crystal ball exercise which I think I wouldn't like to enter into too much.
For the pricing effects of Rebif in the first quarter and so on, may I suggest that you get in touch with Investor Relations after the call to get details, if they are needed, for your models.
On Rebif new formulation, as I said before, we're still waiting for study results, so it's too early to say when we can submit it for registration.

OLED, I still do have the impression that in the TV and display related sector, Liquid Crystal will remain the commanding technology for many years to come. It's a little bit of yo-yo with OLED. Sometimes everybody thinks OLED will be there tomorrow, next day everybody says, no, it will come in 10 years. So my working assumption is that in the display technologies, Liquid Crystals will remain the leading technologies for many years to come.

In lighting I see better chances for the organic lighting devices and when we open the new material research center here in Darmstadt I was saying that we could hope to be able to tell you more about that in 2012 and that related mainly to lighting.
On ForEx Michael Becker will add a brief comment and Stimuvax and cilengitide questions will be then answered by Bernhard.

Okay. To foreign exchange effect on top and bottom line, I understand you meant full year 2010, the currency effect on sales is roughly €270 million plus of course and on total revenues roughly €280 million out of which €10 million flowed through to the bottom line. That is the effect that what a tailwind is for sales and revenues is a headwind for the cost lines.
So, maybe just wanted a short comment in regards to the Rebif U.S. and Europe there was not a discernable difference in organic growth between either region for 2010 for the full year for Rebif.

So with that, that is all the time we have allotted for today's session. I'd like to turn the conference over to Dr. Kley for some closing remarks. We will have a rebroadcast of this call posted to our website a couple of hours after the event.
So with that I'd like to turn it over to Dr. Kley for some closing remarks.

Yeah. There were two questions on Stimuvax and cilengitide, I was just reminded. On Stimuvax, I just mentioned before that the recruitment in the study is going very well. So we planned to recruit 1,500 patients, we are getting closer. And – but in terms of speculating what the exact timeline is, we don't do this.
And cilengitide, glioblastoma going as planned but no further comments on the timelines.

In closing, I think we delivered good numbers in a challenging year. The potential in our portfolio is good. The only one who can prevent us from delivering is ourselves. So it's mainly calling ourselves to deliver what we have in hand. I believe that we outlined the opportunities and the headwinds and challenges and believe on that note that good a 2010 will be followed by a good 2011.
Looking forward to continued and extensive communication with you, all the best. Take care. Bye, bye.
